attributes.body: Triple-threat Teddy Abrams is often dubbed “the new Leonard Bernstein,” and in true Bernsteinian fashion, this gifted musician has transformed the classical scene in Louisville, Kentucky, where he is music director of the Louisville Orchestra. A tireless advocate for the transformational power of music, this Michael Tilson Thomas protégé also runs the Britt Festival in Jacksonville, Oregon, where some of his cooler initiatives include anointing “conducting” fellows (in which the likes of composer-in-residence Caroline Shaw will be instructed in the art of baton-wielding) and orchestral fellowships that give aspiring string players a much-needed stepping-stone into the industry. In his downtime — of which there can’t be much — Abrams also plays clarinet and leads the genre-blending Sixth Floor Trio.

image-main.name: 2019/01/TeddyAbrams.jpg
image-main.credits-name: Chris Wietzke courtesy of Louisville Orchestra

attributes.tease: Sometimes dubbed the "next Leonard Bernstein," meet Teddy Abrams, music director of the Louisville Orchestra.
attributes.title: Teddy Abrams

attributes.body: New York-based Israeli pianist Inon Barnatan is so admired by audiences and musicians alike that his fellow artists fall over themselves to collaborate with him — meaning his dance card is perpetually full. Musically speaking, what we love best of all about Barnatan is his sheer range. Not only does he slay the Romantic repertoire (he has been dubbed “a born Schubertian,” and he’s a Chopin, Mendelssohn and Rachmaninoff master as well), but he’s also fully at home performing more recent works. His reading of Messiaen’s From the Canyons to the Stars might just be definitive, and he’s a brilliant advocate for contemporary voices such as Thomas Adès and Matthias Pintscher. Having recently finished his term as the New York Philharmonic’s first-ever artist-in-residence, in 2019 Barnatan becomes music director of La Jolla Music Society Summerfest, and we can’t wait to see how he brings his musical intelligence, poetic sensibility and innate sense of fun to the proceedings. Barnatan performs live at The Greene Space for the launch of our “19 for 19” project on January 31.
attributes.tease: New York-based Israeli pianist Inon Barnatan is so admired by audiences and musicians alike that his fellow artists fall over themselves to collaborate with him.
attributes.title: Inon Barnatan

attributes.body: The multiple-award-winning Scottish violinist burst onto the classical scene in 2004 when, aged just 16, she won the prestigious BBC Young Musician of the Year competition performing Szymanowski’s First Violin Concerto in front of a television audience of millions. Since then, she has released nine chart-storming albums, been honored multiple times by Her Majesty the Queen for services to music and education and headlined numerous major classical events around the world. Now Benedetti is set for a busier-than-ever 2019: Before the end of January, she gives the world premiere of a new piece by jazz legend Wynton Marsalis (who wrote his 2015 violin concerto for her) at New York’s 92nd Street Y. For an exclusive sneak preview, join us for a special event featuring Benedetti and Marsalis live at The Greene Space on January 16th.
attributes.tease: Violinist Nicola Benedetti has released nine chart-storming albums, and been honored multiple times by Her Majesty the Queen for services to music and education.
attributes.title: Nicola Benedetti

attributes.body: This award-winning Harlem-based mezzo wowed audiences at The Greene Space and on WQXR when she performed at our holiday party in December, shortly after making her Carnegie Hall debut. The recipient of the Sphinx Medal of Excellence in 2018, Bridges, brings a rare combination of luminosity and gravitas to every note she sings — and is a sensational actress to boot. Which is handy, as her opera career is going spectacularly: Next month she makes her house debut at Dutch National Opera as Josefa Segovia in John Adams’s Girls of the Golden West, a role she created at San Francisco Opera in 2017 (alongside fellow WQXR 19-ers Julia Bullock and Davóne Tines). She returns to San Francisco as Carmen this June, then makes a house debut in Barcelona in Verdi’s Luisa Miller. Bridges’ Instagram bio states that her mission is to change the world “one note at a time.” J’Nai: we’re with you every step of the way.
attributes.tease: Mezzo-Soprano J'Nai Bridges brings a rare combination of luminosity and gravitas to every note she sings — and is a sensational actress to boot.
attributes.title: J'Nai Bridges

attributes.body: Speaking of changing the world, every so often an artist comes along who, quite simply, has it all. Julia Bullock is one of them. This radiant soprano boasts an unforgettable stage presence and a voice from heaven — we get shivers just thinking about it. But perhaps more than anything, it’s how Bullock puts that oh-so-resonant voice to use that most impress us. A deep thinker and probing intellect, she considers her role as a socially-conscious activist as important as any note she sings. Her performances and commissions as artist-in-residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been, so far, exercises in groundbreaking and thought-provoking wonder, as well as consummate musical artistry and aesthetic delight. Her upcoming project Zauberland is a radical and timely new treatment of Schumann’s song-cycle Dichterliebe, in which a young woman flees violence in the Middle East only to be held at the border of Fortress Europe, dreaming of entering a magical if elusive land. Also on the bill for 2019 is a trek to Amsterdam for John Adams’s Girls of the Golden West and the world premiere of Terence Blanchard’s Fire Shut Up In My Bones at Opera Theatre of Saint Louis.
attributes.tease: Every so often an artist comes along who, quite simply, has it all. Julia Bullock is one of them.
attributes.title: Julia Bullock

attributes.body: Already something of a fixture at the Metropolitan Opera, where he has delighted audiences and critics alike in productions such as Nico Muhly’s Marnie, Thomas Adès’s The Exterminating Angel and Handel’s Rodelinda, the Grammy-winning British countertenor also recently wowed Broadway with his turn as castrato Farinelli in Farinelli and the King alongside Oscar-winning actor Mark Rylance. One of the world’s leading Handelians, Davies is also a terrific advocate for the versatility of the modern countertenor, as comfortable singing contemporary music — even pop — as he is with core baroque repertoire. His breathtaking vocal dexterity is complemented by some serious intellectual chops, too — he majored in archaeology and anthropology at Cambridge. In 2019, Davies is set for his busiest year yet: As well as a major new album and a busy European schedule, he sings Polinesso in Handel’s Ariodante at Lyric Opera of Chicago and gives concerts in Berkeley, Montreal and Washington, D.C. In May, he returns to Carnegie Hall with a program celebrating Orpheus — that legendary Greek hero who boasted superhuman musical powers. A fitting subject indeed.
attributes.tease: One of the world’s leading Handelians, Davies is also an advocate for the versatility of the modern countertenor, comfortable singing both contemporary music and core baroque repertoire.
attributes.title: Iestyn Davies

attributes.body: Throughout his career, Iranian-American Mahan Esfahani has been making a particularly strong case for ushering harpsichord performance practice into the modern era. If you’ve yet to experience his work, allow yourself to be challenged in the best possible way as he encourages you to consider the harpsichord unbound by the straightjacket of history: “Until (it) has the presence that any other mainstream instrument has,” he notes, “my work isn’t done.” Hot on the heels of his acclaimed Carnegie Hall debut last year (in which New Yorker critic Alex Ross singled out his “exuberant, anti-sentimental” playing), in 2019 he crosses the U.S. evangelizing for all that is good about the harpsichord. He has concert dates with the Seattle Symphony, an engagement at Indiana’s Purdue University and a collaboration with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at the 92nd Street Y.
attributes.tease: Iranian-American Mahan Esfahani makes a particularly strong case for ushering harpsichord performance practice into the modern era.
attributes.title: Mahan Esfahani

attributes.body: “He’s extraordinary: there’s nothing this guy cannot do. He is absolutely captivating,” says Chi-Chi Nwanoku (award-winning double-bass guru) about the young American bassist Xavier Foley. He took first prize in the 2014 Sphinx Competition and has gone on to perform on such hallowed stages as Carnegie Hall and with such prestigious outfits as The Philadelphia Orchestra. As well as being a highly-engaging and soulful player, Foley is a fine composer. He studied at the Curtis Institute with Edgar Meyer, whose own creative versatility across musical genres including classical, jazz, bluegrass and folk is reflected in Foley’s refreshingly fluid approach to styles. It’s fair to say there aren’t too many solo bassists who hit the big time — this extraordinary instrument, so often the foundation of the musical structures we love, is invariably taken for granted at the back of any ensemble. But Foley says he is determined to be taken seriously as a bassist on the world stage, and with talent this great, you’d be a fool to bet against him.
attributes.tease: Bassist and composer Xavier Foley says he is determined to be taken seriously as a bassist on the world stage, and with talent this great, you’d be a fool to bet against him.
attributes.title: Xavier Foley

attributes.body: Nobody who watched The Last Night of the Proms in 2018 could miss the star turn by classical saxophonist Jess Gillam — one critic described her, correctly, as “stealing the show.” Indeed, this coolest of cats looked as though she had been born to play the Royal Albert Hall in front of 6,000 people (and millions more on TV) before her 20th birthday. Gillam’s onstage charisma and virtuosity is matched offstage by her entrepreneurial zeal, making her the perfect ambassador for her instrument. No wonder she was quickly snapped up by Decca, becoming — at just 19 — the first-ever saxophonist to sign with the label. The spirited young trailblazer, who already has a Classical Brit award under her belt, also runs her own festival and cites David Bowie as a hero. In 2019, Gillam will release her hotly-anticipated first album and has concert engagements all over Europe, from Barcelona to Finland to Lucerne. On this side of the pond, we’re delighted she will bring her magic to our “19 for 19” launch at The Greene Space on January 31 before heading to Washington, D.C., to give her debut U.S. solo recital at The Phillips Collection.
attributes.tease: Saxophonist Jess Gillam was the first-ever saxophonist to sign with Decca, and already runs her own festival.
attributes.title: Jess Gillam

attributes.body: The majestic British cellist has recently celebrated his 60th birthday with a slew of new accolades (including the U.S.–based Maestro Foundation Genius Award), and he seems to be approaching his next decade with a renewed sense of vigor, curiosity and joy. In 2019, in addition to a jam-packed international concert schedule, he teams up with besties Joshua Bell (violin) and Jeremy Denk (piano) for an 11-city U.S. tour, performing music by Mendelssohn, Shostakovich, Ravel and Rachmaninoff. An ever-inventive programmer, Isserlis has also devised an intriguing new concert series called Composers & Their Muses, which explores three pairs of composers who inspired each other, including Brahms and Clara Schumann. His latest album will be released February 1, featuring music by Shostakovich, Prokofiev and Kabalevsky. All three lived under the tyranny of Stalin, and found extraordinary ways to communicate through the power of music — something Isserlis does every single time he puts bow to string.
attributes.tease: British cellist Steven Isserlis recently celebrated his 60th birthday with a slew of accolades and approaches his next decade with a renewed sense of vigor, curiosity and joy.
attributes.title: Steven Isserlis

attributes.body: It’s no secret that 2018 was a career-defining year for the cellist from Nottingham, England. It’s fair to say great multitudes of people had their first Kanneh-Mason experience (and possibly their first taste of the cello) during May’s royal wedding, as Harry and Meghan signed the register. Social media went duly nuts, spawning memes and quickfire hashtags, such as #cellobae. Yet the teenager had already started to build an impressive career for himself. After winning the coveted BBC Young Musician of the Year title in 2016, in 2017 he made his Carnegie Hall debut in The Children’s Monologues, directed by Danny Boyle. In 2018 (aside from that wedding) he released his chart-topping debut album, Inspiration, becoming the youngest cellist to crack the UK Top 100. Kanneh-Mason rides high into 2019, with stints in New Orleans, Poland, Paris and a three-concert run in Atlanta.
attributes.tease: In 2018, the teenaged Sheku Kanneh-Mason became the youngest cellist to crack the UK Top 100.
attributes.title: Sheku Kanneh-Mason

attributes.body: Still just 19 and a student at Philadelphia’s Curtis Institute, Wei Luo has taken first prize in multiple competitions in her native China and is the recipient of the 2018 Gilmore Young Artist Award. A student of the legendary Gary Graffman, who also taught Lang Lang and Yuja Wang, she has already signed to Decca Gold — whose roster includes the likes of Daniil Trifonov, Reneé Fleming, Anna Netrebko and Lang Lang. WQXR heard a sneak preview of her debut album (due for release this year and featuring Haydn, Prokofiev, Ravel and Shostakovich), and we were absolutely blown away, not only by her pyrotechnical virtuosity but by the range of musical colors she teased from the keys. When you’re in the presence of truly great artistry, you just know it — and trust us, Wei Luo has it. We’re thrilled she’ll make her debut at The Greene Space on January 31, alongside fellow members of our 19. Remember her name: you heard it here first.
attributes.tease: A student of the legendary Gary Graffman, who also taught Lang Lang and Yuja Wang, pianist Wei Luo has already signed to Decca Gold.
attributes.title: Wei Luo

attributes.body: Meyers has been busy on the international professional scene since she was 10 years old. She has a host of honors to her name, but is not one to rest on her laurels. Her 2019 is another year filled with premieres, outreach initiatives and new collaborations. Having given the world premiere in 2015 of Einojuhani Rautavaara’s final work, Fantasia, Meyers resurrects it for its Asian premiere in Japan. In the spring, she heads to London for the launch of The Strad’s new educational conference. On this side of the Atlantic, she tours with classical guitarist Jason Vieaux, and joins the Pasadena Symphony for Adam Schoenberg’s Orchard in Fog, written especially for Meyers. Down the road, she’ll play commissions from Arturo Márquez, Michael Daugherty and Julia Adolphe. Catch her live at The Greene Space on January 31, performing music by Arvo Pärt, John Corigliano and John Williams.

image-main.alt-text: Anne Akiko Meyers' latest recording, 'The Four Seasons: The Vivaldi Album,' is out now.
image-main.name: 1/AnneAkikoMeyers_wide.jpg
image-main.caption: Anne Akiko Meyers' latest recording, 'The Four Seasons: The Vivaldi Album,' is out now.

attributes.tease: Violinist Anne Akiko Meyers has been busy on the international scene since she was 10 years old, and 2019 is another year filled with premieres, outreach initiatives and collaborations.
attributes.title: Anne Akiko Meyers

attributes.body: Rana made an international splash as the Silver Medalist of the 14th Van Cliburn competition — a decade after her orchestral debut at just nine years old. A 2018 Classic BRIT Awards nominee for Best Female Artist of the Year, Rana is certainly a young artist to keep on any music lover’s radar. Her 2017 recording of Bach’s The Goldberg Variations made hers a name often spoken in the WQXR office, and earned her a place on that year’s best overall albums list. Rana tours tirelessly in 2019, traveling between various cities in the U.K., Italy and Germany in a matter of days. In New York, Rana appears twice at Carnegie Hall, first for her recital debut at Zankel Hall in March, and in June for the final concert of the season, joining Yannick Nézet-Séguin and The Philadelphia Orchestra for Prokofiev’s Piano Concerto No. 3.
attributes.tease: A 2018 Classic BRIT Awards nominee for Best Female Artist of the Year, pianist Beatrice Rana is certainly a young artist to keep on any music lover’s radar.
attributes.title: Beatrice Rana

attributes.body: A hearty chunk of the opera world still suffers from a perception of exclusivity and white privilege that inadvertently shuts out many who might otherwise curious to the medium. That is unfortunate. What is fortunate, though, is the work of baritone Davóne Tines, who is committed to using his musical platform as a vehicle to advocate for change and advance some of the most uncomfortable, albeit necessary, conversations about art and race. Sure, Tines is comfortable in roles in Verdi’s Otello and Puccini’s La Bohème, but in his opinion, “opera is not a monolith,” and requires its practitioners to constantly engage with the art form and stretch it to new limits. That might mean exploring the contemporary work of composers like Kaija Saariaho, or creating the musical play The Black Clown, based on Langston Hughes’s poem of the same name. In 2019, he continues his artistic conversation in John Adams’s Girls of the Golden West, Hans Werner Henze’s El Cimarrón (The Runaway Slave) and Terrence Blanchard’s Fire Shut Up In My Bones, alongside Julia Bullock.
attributes.tease: Baritone Davóne Tines uses his musical platform to advance some of the most uncomfortable, albeit necessary, conversations about art and race.
attributes.title: Davóne Tines

attributes.body: It’s often said that contemporary classical artists need to approach their careers with a degree of flexibility, and violinist Elena Urioste takes that literally. The self-confessed “yoga fanatic” recently co-founded (with fellow violinist Melissa White) a music and yoga program called Intermission, which addresses how the physical toll of being a professional musician is largely overlooked. A first-prize laureate in the Sphinx Competition, Urioste made her debut at Carnegie Hall some 15 years ago, and since then has performed with some of the world’s greats, including the New York, Los Angeles and London philharmonics, the Philadelphia and Cleveland orchestras and the Chicago and San Francisco symphony orchestras. This season she plays such monuments of the solo repertoire as the Beethoven, Barber, Korngold and Tchaikovsky concertos. Equally devoted to chamber music, her latest album is Estrellita, a collection of glittering miniatures performed with pianist Tom Poster. She recently described the project as their bid to bring “even a teensy amount of joy to the world.” Urioste, who also writes an engaging and thought-provoking blog, has certainly come a long way since watching a 1998 episode of Sesame Street featuring Itzhak Perlman when she was only two. We can’t wait to see what she gets up to next.
attributes.tease: It’s often said that contemporary classical artists need to approach their careers with a degree of flexibility, and violinist Elena Urioste takes that literally.
attributes.title: Elena Urioste

attributes.body: When you find out the JACK Quartet is coming to town, you know it’s bringing something fresh. New music and living composers have become a central part of the group’s musical identity — this season alone it performs no fewer than five world premieres. Following the unveiling of Cristina García Islas’s String Quartet No. 1, Skeleton Leaves, and Michel Roth’s (w)hole, 2019 includes new music from Ryan Carter, Christopher Otto and Miya Masaoka. Also passionately committed to education, the JACK carves considerable time out of its busy schedule to teach on residency programs all over the U.S. Here at WQXR, we’ve been let in on some big, but as yet still-secret news that will be announced later in the year. We’re excited: watch this space.
attributes.tease: New music and living composers have become a central part of string quartet JACK Quartet's musical identity — this season alone it performs no fewer than five world premieres.
attributes.title: JACK Quartet

attributes.body: The creative brainchild of brothers Colin and Eric Jacobsen, The Knights emerged from a number of informal chamber music reading parties. Although the ensemble defies easy categorization, it might best be described as a collective that wants its performances to be as culturally relevant as they are technically sound. While based in Brooklyn (The Knights are artists-in-residence at BRIC), the ensemble collaborates with artists from beyond the borough, considers musical influences from across the globe and often presents the work of composers with a similar artistic outlook, building their own unique, borderless sound. Consider 2017’s album Azul, featuring Osvaldo Golijov’s composition of the same name as performed by the orchestra and Yo-Yo Ma, Caroline Shaw’s arrangement of Stockhausen and a bounty of interpretations of music by Sufjan Stevens. This year The Knights trek across Europe in a 13-city tour with Israeli mandolinist Avi Avital, and drop into Zankel Hall with Syrian clarinetist Kinan Azmeh. Before that, you can witness the group’s electrifying brand of music-making live at The Greene Space on 31 January as part of our “19 for 19” launch event.
attributes.tease: Chamber ensemble The Knights wants its performances to be as culturally relevant as they are technically sound.
attributes.title: The Knights

attributes.body: What does it really mean to make opera in the 21st century? That’s the question that keeps the artists of American Modern Opera Company up at night, and those of us that love the art form should all be grateful for it. It’s hard to think of more compelling advocates for the cause than co-founders Matt Aucoin, a composer and conductor who recently won a MacArthur “Genius” grant, and Zack Winokur, who’s been behind some of the most interesting productions we have seen on stages and concert halls anywhere lately. The core company – which includes the likes of our favorites Julia Bullock and Davóne Tines – focuses on long-term artistic relationships and discipline-colliding collaborations that address – with radical brilliance and joy - some of the most pressing issues of our time, including race, gender and social justice.
attributes.tease: What does it really mean to make opera in the 21st century? That’s the question that keeps the American Modern Opera Company up at night, and we should all be grateful for it..
attributes.title: American Modern Opera Company
